review.title: Evidential supplier selection based on interval data fusion
review.abstract: Supplier selection is a typical multi-criteria decision making (MCDM) problem and lots of uncertain information exist inevitably. To address this issue, a new method was proposed based on interval data fusion. Our method follows the original way to generate classical basic probability assignment(BPA) determined by the distance among the evidences. However, the weights of criteria are kept as interval numbers to generate interval BPAs and do the fusion of interval BPAs. Finally, the order is ranked and the decision is made according to the obtained interval BPAs. In this paper, a numerical example of supplier selection is applied to verify the feasibility and validity of our method. The new method is presented aiming at solving multiple-criteria decision-making problems in which the weights of criteria or experts are described in fuzzy data like linguistic terms or interval data.

metadata.title: Evidential supplier selection based on interval data fusion

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 3.01 971v 1 [cs.A I] Supplier selection is a typical multi-criterion decision problem (MCDM) and there is bound to be a lot of uncertain information. To solve this problem, a new method based on interval data fusion has been proposed. Our method follows the original way of generating classic basic probability mapping (BPA), which is determined by the distance between the evidences. However, the criterion weights are retained as interval numbers to generate interval BPAs and merge interval BPAs. Finally, the sequence is ranked and the decision is made according to the interval BPAs obtained. In this paper, a numerical example of supplier selection is used to verify the feasibility and validity of our method. The new method is presented with the aim of solving multiplex decision problems where the weights are described by criteria or expert in blurred data such as interval data.

sections.text: To address this problem, a new method is proposed based on the merging of interval data. Blurred data is collected in the form of interval data in our methodology.24Compared to the original method, our method has remarkable superiority in dealing with the blurred information. An example of supplier selection serves to illustrate the detailed approach of our method and the result proves its accuracy sufficiently. Our new method is worth considering if the blurred data grows rapidly with the development of the system. In addition, our method has numerous applications, especially in areas such as social, economic and so on.
